page.title: 09Historic Settlements
page.content: Many historic settlements and features such as ridge and furrow have been ploughed out.Such is the fate of the last traces of an old settlement, Dilwick, which was one of the 5 manors in the parish of Stagsden in 1086 (with Bosums, Dokesworth, Burdelys and Beauchamp). Ancient hedgerows may mark old administrative boundaries (hundreds, parishes, manors) Where current boundaries are irregular there is often an interesting reason.e.g. the long tongue of Kempston Rural Parish represents the 12th century clearance of wood and waste and extension of cultivation.The enlargement of a deer park in the 15th century is the reason behind the diversion of the Stagsden boundary away from the Ridgeway.This perhaps also led to the demise of Dilwick.
